004
005package edu.wpi.first.math.controller;
006
007import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.proto.ArmFeedforwardProto;
008import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.struct.ArmFeedforwardStruct;
009import edu.wpi.first.math.jni.ArmFeedforwardJNI;
010import edu.wpi.first.util.protobuf.ProtobufSerializable;
011import edu.wpi.first.util.struct.StructSerializable;
012
013/**
014 * A helper class that computes feedforward outputs for a simple arm (modeled as a motor acting
015 * against the force of gravity on a beam suspended at an angle).
016 */
017public class ArmFeedforward implements ProtobufSerializable, StructSerializable {
018  /** The static gain, in volts. */
019  private final double ks;
020
021  /** The gravity gain, in volts. */
022  private final double kg;
023
024  /** The velocity gain, in V/(rad/s). */
025  private final double kv;
026
027  /** The acceleration gain, in V/(rad/s²). */
028  private final double ka;
029
030  /** Arm feedforward protobuf for serialization. */
031  public static final ArmFeedforwardProto proto = new ArmFeedforwardProto();
032
033  /** Arm feedforward struct for serialization. */
034  public static final ArmFeedforwardStruct struct = new ArmFeedforwardStruct();
035
036  /**
037   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains. Units of the gain values will dictate
038   * units of the computed feedforward.
039   *
040   * @param ks The static gain.
041   * @param kg The gravity gain.
042   * @param kv The velocity gain.
043   * @param ka The acceleration gain.
044   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
045   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for ka &lt; zero.
046   */
047  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kg, double kv, double ka) {
048    this.ks = ks;
049    this.kg = kg;
050    this.kv = kv;
051    this.ka = ka;
052    if (kv < 0.0) {
053      throw new IllegalArgumentException("kv must be a non-negative number, got " + kv + "!");
054    }
055    if (ka < 0.0) {
056      throw new IllegalArgumentException("ka must be a non-negative number, got " + ka + "!");
057    }
058  }
059
060  /**
061   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains. Acceleration gain is defaulted to zero.
062   * Units of the gain values will dictate units of the computed feedforward.
063   *
064   * @param ks The static gain.
065   * @param kg The gravity gain.
066   * @param kv The velocity gain.
067   */
068  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kg, double kv) {
069    this(ks, kg, kv, 0);
070  }
071
072  /**
073   * Returns the static gain.
074   *
075   * @return The static gain, in volts.
076   */
077  public double getKs() {
078    return ks;
079  }
080
081  /**
082   * Returns the gravity gain.
083   *
084   * @return The gravity gain, in volts.
085   */
086  public double getKg() {
087    return kg;
088  }
089
090  /**
091   * Returns the velocity gain.
092   *
093   * @return The velocity gain, in V/(rad/s).
094   */
095  public double getKv() {
096    return kv;
097  }
098
099  /**
100   * Returns the acceleration gain.
101   *
102   * @return The acceleration gain, in V/(rad/s²).
103   */
104  public double getKa() {
105    return ka;
106  }
107
108  /**
109   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints.
110   *
111   * @param positionRadians The position (angle) setpoint. This angle should be measured from the
112   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
113   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
114   * @param velocityRadPerSec The velocity setpoint.
115   * @param accelRadPerSecSquared The acceleration setpoint.
116   * @return The computed feedforward.
117   */
118  public double calculate(
119      double positionRadians, double velocityRadPerSec, double accelRadPerSecSquared) {
120    return ks * Math.signum(velocityRadPerSec)
121        + kg * Math.cos(positionRadians)
122        + kv * velocityRadPerSec
123        + ka * accelRadPerSecSquared;
124  }
125
126  /**
127   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and velocity setpoint (acceleration is assumed to be
128   * zero).
129   *
130   * @param positionRadians The position (angle) setpoint. This angle should be measured from the
131   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
132   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
133   * @param velocity The velocity setpoint.
134   * @return The computed feedforward.
135   */
136  public double calculate(double positionRadians, double velocity) {
137    return calculate(positionRadians, velocity, 0);
138  }
139
140  /**
141   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints.
142   *
143   * @param currentAngle The current angle in radians. This angle should be measured from the
144   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel to the floor). If
145   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
146   * @param currentVelocity The current velocity setpoint in radians per second.
147   * @param nextVelocity The next velocity setpoint in radians per second.
148   * @param dt Time between velocity setpoints in seconds.
149   * @return The computed feedforward in volts.
150   */
151  public double calculate(
152      double currentAngle, double currentVelocity, double nextVelocity, double dt) {
153    return ArmFeedforwardJNI.calculate(
154        ks, kv, ka, kg, currentAngle, currentVelocity, nextVelocity, dt);
155  }
156
157  // Rearranging the main equation from the calculate() method yields the
158  // formulas for the methods below:
159
160  /**
161   * Calculates the maximum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and an
162   * acceleration. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
163   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give
164   * you a simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
165   *
166   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
167   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
168   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
169   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
170   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the arm.
171   * @return The maximum possible velocity at the given acceleration and angle.
172   */
173  public double maxAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double angle, double acceleration) {
174    // Assume max velocity is positive
175    return (maxVoltage - ks - Math.cos(angle) * kg - acceleration * ka) / kv;
176  }
177
178  /**
179   * Calculates the minimum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and an
180   * acceleration. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
181   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give
182   * you a simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
183   *
184   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
185   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
186   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
187   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
188   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the arm.
189   * @return The minimum possible velocity at the given acceleration and angle.
190   */
191  public double minAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double angle, double acceleration) {
192    // Assume min velocity is negative, ks flips sign
193    return (-maxVoltage + ks - Math.cos(angle) * kg - acceleration * ka) / kv;
194  }
195
196  /**
197   * Calculates the maximum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and
198   * a velocity. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
199   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
200   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
201   *
202   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
203   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
204   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
205   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
206   * @param velocity The velocity of the arm.
207   * @return The maximum possible acceleration at the given velocity.
208   */
209  public double maxAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double angle, double velocity) {
210    return (maxVoltage - ks * Math.signum(velocity) - Math.cos(angle) * kg - velocity * kv) / ka;
211  }
212
213  /**
214   * Calculates the minimum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and
215   * a velocity. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
216   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
217   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
218   *
219   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
220   * @param angle The angle of the arm. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e. if
221   *     the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If your encoder does
222   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
223   * @param velocity The velocity of the arm.
224   * @return The minimum possible acceleration at the given velocity.
225   */
226  public double minAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double angle, double velocity) {
227    return maxAchievableAcceleration(-maxVoltage, angle, velocity);
228  }
229}
